titleproper.value: Guide to the Abraham I. Katsh Papers <num>MC 26</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-02-12T15:26:06</date>

extent.value: in three record cartons, one half manuscript box, and eight flat boxes

abstract.value: Abraham Isaac Katsh was an alumnus of New York University (NYU) and served on the faculty from 1933 until 1967, when he became the president of Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning.  During his time at NYU, Katsh established the first course in modern Hebrew at an American university, and helped found the Jewish Culture Foundation.  His role in creating courses in Hebrew language, culture and education led to the endowment of a chair in that field in his name.  Katsh was a prolific writer and researcher and published numerous books and articles on a wide variety of topics in the field of Hebrew and Judaic studies. This collection documents Katsh's career at NYU and demonstrates Katsh's active involvement in promoting Hebrew as a course of study in American higher education in general. Materials include correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, clippings, articles, administrative files, programs, and speech notes.

p.value: Repository permission is required for access. Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the New York University Archives, (212) 998-2641, university-archives@nyu.edu with specific questions regarding access to such records.
Identification of item, date;  Abraham I. Katsh Papers; MC 26; box number; folder number or item identifier; New York University Archives, New York University.
Donated by Abraham I. Katsh in 1979. The accession number associated with this gift is 85.057.

The Abraham I. Katsh Papers document Katsh's career at NYU, particularly his role in founding the Jewish Culture Foundation and his work in establishing courses in Modern Hebrew language, literature and culture.  The papers also demonstrate Katsh's active involvement in promoting Hebrew as a course of study in American higher education in general.  Katsh's trips to the Soviet Union and his correspondence with Jewish leaders there in the 1950s and 1960s is also well documented in the scrapbooks, correspondence and articles in the collection.   
Katsh's early life, his time as a student at NYU, his tenure at Dropsie College and the last decade of his life are, for the most part, not included in the scope of this collection.

corpname.value: New York University. Library of Judaica and Hebraica

dsc.value:
Series I: Correspondence1900-1986Conditions Governing Access

Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Restricted materials have been moved to separate folders within the box and are noted as restricted.

Scope and Contents

The "Correspondence" series is extremely comprehensive, and includes letters to Katsh from academics and notables in the field of Hebrew and/or Judaic studies, largely from Israel or America. There are also a number of letters to Katsh from representatives of the Jewish community in the Soviet Union. This series is arranged chronologically.

Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Restricted materials have been moved to separate folders within the box and are noted as restricted.

Scope and Contents

The "Articles and Clippings' series consists mainly of articles written by Dr. Katsh for newspapers and scholarly journals. Articles written by others about Katsh were preserved in Katsh's scrapbooks, along with a limited amount of correspondence.

Scope and Contents

"Event Files" includes programs and speech notes from events at which Katsh spoke or was honored over the course of his career.

Event Files1905, 1935-1963218Event Files1940-1967, undated219Event Files1940-1985220Event Files1941-1977221Event Files1942-1970222Event Files1945-197131Event Files1946-197732Event Files1948-197634Event Files1952-198335Event Files1961-1976, undated36Series IV: Administrative Papers1926-1983Conditions Governing Access

Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Restricted materials have been moved to separate folders within the box and are noted as restricted.

Scope and Contents

"Administrative Papers" consists largely of NYU publications, press releases and schedules, along with those from other organizations for the study of Hebrew language with which Katsh was involved.

Hebrew Language, Culture and Education Pamphlets1958-196237Administrative Papers1926-1969, undated38Administrative Papers1930-1971, undated39Administrative Papers1934-1978310Administrative Papers1942-1969311Administrative Papers1944-1965312Administrative Papers1947-1975313Administrative Papers1950-1973314Administrative Papers1953-1980315Administrative Papers1954-1983, undated316Administrative Papers1955-1966317Administrative Papers1956-1962, undated318Administrative Papers1972-1976, undated319Executive Committee Meetings book1940-195341Series V: Scrapbooks Scope and Contents

The "scrapbooks" series consists of scrapbooks that Katsh created to document his career and achievements. The scrapbooks contain mostly newspaper clippings, many of which are reviews of Katsh's books, as well as a few pieces of correspondence and articles published by Katsh.
